art_description: The first model that Brooklyn-born artist Ray Ring submitted for the Clark Street Station renovation in 1983 was a three-dimensional work to be attached to the arched ceiling of the passageway that led from the elevators to the platform, but after discussion this was transformed into a floor piece.  The artist points out, ÒThe  Passage uses three geometric shapes Ð a circle, a square, and a triangle Ð that turn in four different directions.  The floor of the subway corridor is divided into large black squares.  As people walk down the passage they experience all the possible combinations of these elements.  The study of ever-changing geometric patterns comes out of  my earlier work from the 1970s that were shown in an exhibition entitled 2048 Variations on a Drawing by Malevich.  Today, I continue to work in variations of geometric shapes.  My latest pieces utilize computers to help generate large three-dimensional constructions.Ó

The Open Secret, in the 125th Street and Lexington Avenue station, was the first Arts for Transit commission to be installed in the subway.  The work presents various themes that had long intrigued artist Houston Conwill.  Here, he says, he attempts Òto capture the present for future generations of people through a ritual process; the creation of sacred spaces; and the involvement of a community of people in bearing witness to the process and making it complete,Ó as he put it in his artistÕs statement for the work.  

There is also a mysterious aspect to The Open Secret, to which its title alludes.  For if some future archaeologist breaks it apart, two of its triangular segments, if opened up, will be found to contain time capsules Òholding information and ÔsecretsÕ about a certain place at a certain time Ð Harlem in the 1980s.Ó  Covered with grates so viewers can peer into them, the other two triangular elements reveal a variety of objects.  As Conwill observed in his proposal for the project, ÒThe exploration might be of a place or into our own minds where we might find eternal secrets that are saved and put in the time capsules for our children and their children.Ó 

The leading encyclopedia of African and African American experience, Africana, includes Conwill as one of the Òpioneers of African American visual postmodernism.Ó  
Examples of his public art can be found throughout the nation Ð from New York to San Francisco, Niagara Falls to Miami.  He often works in collaboration with other artists, for instance his sister Estella Conwill M‡jozo, a poet.  The themes of the works often involve the history of African Americans and their quest for freedom and equality.

Milton Glaser, best known for his work in graphics, printmaking, and as a teacher, was approached to augment Rolf OlhausenÕs architectural plans for the restoration/ redesign of Astor Place station.  This was an interesting challenge, since the station boasted some of the most beautiful historic terra cotta and mosaics in the transportation system but at the same time required a large-scale redesign in order to make it function in todayÕs world.  GlaserÕs response was to meld the two  Ð to use the historic Grueby Faience Company plaques (which depicted beavers, a reference to the Astor fortune partly acquired though fur trading) as a springboard for his thoroughly modern design.  

In the artistÕs words,

The design concept É is basically a variation on the existing forms.  By extracting fragments of the motifs on the tile panels, enlarging their scale, and placing these pieces in a random pattern, they take on the appearance of a large puzzle.  Viewers may perceive these fragments and discover their relationship to the original design motifs.  The resulting dialectic between the previously existing and the new panels inspire an appreciation for the original details of the station.

Glaser was born in New York and has often been at the very center of the cityÕs cultural life, for years chairing the board at New York magazine and teaching at the School of Visual Arts.  And he was especially pleased to be asked to design a work for this particular station:  ÒThis was a wonderful commission, not only because of the proximity of Cooper Union, my alma mater, but I lived on the Lower East Side for years, and itÕs good to see the old neighborhood coming back to life.Ó  (Interestingly, GlaserÕs original design for the station included caricatures of the Astor beaver in addition to the abstract forms Ð but his animals reminded community-board reviewers too much of the rats of those earlier, seedier years that they had worked so hard to eliminate!)

The artist discusses her work:  ÒIf public art is elegantly and permanently crafted, it will delight audiences of the present and the future, in the way the wall paintings of ancient civilizations delight us today, thousands of years after their creation É  Like the ancient pyramids, the subway is a great monument, with underground caverns, and like them, decorated with art.  It is no accident, then, that the style of these murals is hieroglyphs. I wanted the cool dignity, the symbolism full of messages, the cordial sense of humanity in the figures that are found in the Valley of the Kings É  Perhaps some future archaeologist will dig through the layers of Brooklyn, discovering who knows what relics of our civilization, and find these murals, for after all they are forged in enamel, an art form as permanent and enduring as any.  And perhaps he or she will be able to glimpse in them what daily life was like here, in 1987.  I hope so.Ó

The artist recalls, ÒAbout the same time that I was working on a glass public art project at St. George Public Library on Staten Island for New York CityÕs Department of Cultural Affairs, I was chosen to submit a proposal for Newkirk Avenue subway station in Brooklyn.  Because of the need to be resistant to vandalism it was glazed in polycarbonate plastic with zinc extrusions.  I had been interested in the use of plastics and the possibility of ÔleadlinesÕ that are not feasible in glass Ð thus the diagonal ÔcutsÕ going to nowhere in the piece (i.e., stopping in the middle of a color).  Blue was an MTA color at the time and the project is a kind of architectural statement Ð a skylight set into a difficult environment (a steel I-beam divides the triangular window into two halves so that it is hard to read as a whole). Ó

Steve WoodÕs artwork consists of the 160 eight-by-eight-inch bronze relief tiles embedded in the northbound and southbound platform walls of the station, 80 on each side.  Each represents the fossilized remains of biological forms.  From the artistÕs proposal: "The idea behind Fossils is simple: the subway is underground, fossils are found in the earth . . . I wanted these reliefs to be 'scattered' over the walls of the northbound and southbound platforms in such a way that both children and adults would see them personally and close-up. They are meant to be looked at, touched, talked about and remembered."

Valerie JaudonÕs Long Division at the Lexington Avenue and 23rd Street subway station seamlessly combines the practical and the aesthetic.  In its purely functional role, it is a sturdy steel fence serving as a security barrier.  But it is a work of art as well, a beckoning welcome into the subway.  The artist said: ÒThe idea was to make a fence that functions as combination of wall, door, window and column that allows you to see the entire stationÉ, a sort of transparent lens through which people can see where they are going and where they have been.Ó The work is divided into panel units, and when placed together their straight and arched lines form decorative patterns.  The abstract stylized motifs, as well as the way she combines them, are directly related to those in JaudonÕs paintings of that time.  The hard imagery that dominated her canvases became three dimensional while maintaining the sense of hard-edged flatness on the same plane.

The Zeckendorf CompanyÕs Worldwide Plaza at 50th Street and Eighth Avenue provided new station entrances accessible to the mobility impaired, wells that bring natural light into the underground platform areas, and an 8-foot by 68-foot sandblasted granite mural by artist Matt Mullican.  The artist describes the work as being a timeline in etched granite, from records of the site.  ÒIt was once countryside, once had a cabin, and it was also the previous site of Madison Square Garden,Ó said Mullican.  ÒReferencing the iconography of the subway map, the artwork interprets the history of this location through using elements that take you back in time.Ó  The New Yorker, on September 5, 1994, commented, ÒMatt MullicanÕs mural for the 50th Street station on the C and E lines, a sleek, post-Pop design etched into black granite, is smart and sophisticated yet discreet; the artist has recognized that thousands of people will walk by it ten times a week.Ó

artist: Nitza Tufi–o (in collaboration with Grosvenor Neighborhood House Student Muralists)
art_description:
Westside Views is an unusual project.  It was headed up by artist and teacher Nitza Tufi–o, who worked with 17 young people, most of whom attended or were graduates of the high school equivalency program at Grosvenor Neighborhood House.  The project began when the local community board suggested that amenity funds from a developer, the Bromley Company, be applied to a youth-opportunity community improvement project to improve the 86th Street subway station.  After approval by the cityÕs Planning Commission and Board of Estimate, Arts for Transit was designated as the administrator for the undertaking.  

The overarching concept was to help the students to learn by doing, to acquire problem-solving and strategic thinking abilities through a hands-on collaboration with an experienced mentor, someone they could trust and with whom they could bond.  Nitza Tufi–o was an ideal choice for project leader, since she brought with her an interest in helping young people with social and developmental needs and a proven ability to work successfully with novice artists.  

Tufi–o has said of her approach, in a statement for the New York CityÕs Department of Cultural Affairs website:

As an artist, if I take my brushes and my skills and I invest in the lives of young people, then others can see what is possible.  Maybe it will inspire other artists to share their time.  I want the art work to continue and not to die É this is highly political to have young people lead É we need a chain that grows É I believe human beings can do anything, if we find something that would positively influence them. 

Students first participated in a community survey to determine the theme. Then they took photographs of notable sites in the neighborhood and also held interviews with a variety of community residents.  Ultimately, their work was translated into 40 ceramic tiles that speak volumes about the place and time in which they were created.  The students also worked with Pedro Pietri, whose poetry expresses what it is like to be a Puerto Rican in New York, to create a poem to capture the spirit of the neighborhood, its multi-ethnicity, its parks, the foods Ð the flavor of the community.  The poem is captured in tile and installed in the station.

art_material: Bronze and Steel sheet,  Found objects (tin toys, etc.)
art_description: In Arthur GonzalezÕs monumental artwork, large-scale figurative bronze sculptures located at three stations on Metro-North RailroadÕs Harlem-Hudson line, the themes of time and travel are the central focus.  The Finder / The Seekers at Tuckahoe (the first project in the Arts for Transit  Òpercent for artÓ program to be completed and installed at a Metro-North station) includes images of speed and travel in the form of childrenÕs toys below each of its sculptures representing explorers and settlers.  At Crestwood, the sculpture The Discovery is a bronze figure of a girl in a boat who holds a compass with the cardinal directions evoking themes of travel and exploration.  Time Catcher at Fleetwood is a polychrome bronze featuring a historic map of the region and a worker with his tools, an homage to the workers of the railroad.

art_material: Bronze - patinated and Steel sheet, Found object (tin toys, etc.)
art_description: In Arthur GonzalezÕs monumental artwork, large-scale figurative bronze sculptures located at three stations on Metro-North RailroadÕs Harlem-Hudson line, the themes of time and travel are the central focus. Dan SinclairÕs Fast Track and Speedwheels are exuberant assemblages of metal parts including wavy aluminum sheets, steel wheels, brass disks, and copper springs and wires.  They are meant to look strangely at home at the ends of the long underground passage at Grand Central, to Òseem to have grown on the site, Ó observed the March 25, 1991, New Yorker.  Curious riders are invited to make associations and to read varied meanings into the metal collages.  Among other things, they might suggest antiquated machinery, old photograph records, or birds in flight.  ÒI want my sculpture to make people think of the power of the engines that drive the trains, the speed and efficiency of them . . . the sculptures also reflect the architectural elements of Times Square and the Art Deco glamour of Radio City Music Hall,Ó says the artist.  Or as the writer of the New Yorker piece observed, ÒThey remind me of what a hankie would look like if you fluttered it out of a subway-car window.Ó

In the artistÕs words, Ò[This site] is underground, in the 'earth', under an urban settingÉ  Rocks are interspersed among tiles. The rocks in this situation could actually have been a part of the excavation process for the subway tunnel É [and they] thus become a symbol for the process of building the tunnel and for being underground... The path and stairs as well as the tiles É intermingle nature with the man-made. The built aspect of the stairs also alludes to the built environment, the city. The landscape could be the kind of place that was here before this was an urban center É  The curve [of the tunnel] É was also the perfect opportunity to twist the perspective of the staircase to reiterate the curve and suggest the going from one type of environment to another. Aside from the layers of references and meaning, I tried to create a work that would be visually pleasing and could be enjoyed instinctually.Ó

art_material: Copper wire mesh and Stainless steel
art_description: Five Points of Observation, sited on the platform walls of five adjacent subway stations in Queens,  is composed of five colossal six-foot heads made of copper mesh positioned at different angles and inserted in specially cut openings in the windscreen walls that otherwise would block views from the platforms to the streets below.  Positioning themselves in the heads, subway riders can look out onto the world literally through the eyes of the sculptural forms.  The artist created the faces so as to be both multiethnic and androgynous, leaving room for viewers to construct for themselves stories of who these haunting forms might be and what they might signify.  The faces are constructed with steel armatures and a grid of wire mesh, which serves a protective as well as expressive function.  Also, the positioning of the forms varies from station to station, giving them further variety and expressiveness.

art_material: Ceramic tile, red clay, glazes,  WonderBoard panel backing
art_description: Nitza Tufi–oÕs Neo-Boriken murals at 103rd Street refer to people who have come from her native Puerto Rico and other parts of the Caribbean and Latin America and who, in her words, Òhave transplanted themselves from the tropical jungles into New York.Ó  The title of the mural derives from the pre-Columbian Ta•no Indian name for the island of Puerto Rico, ÒBorikenÓ or ÒBoricua.Ó  The ancient Ta•nos also designed the petroglyphs that are alluded to in the mural, accompanying Aztec and Mayan forms.  Tufi–oÕs art is consistently informed by her connections to the people of Latin America, their history and culture both past and present, as well as her training as a teacher.  In this spirit, she has undertaken a number of well-received public art commissions.  Born in Puerto Rico, she was trained first as a graphic artist and then, in Mexico, as a muralist.

Alison SaarÕs Hear the Lone Whistle Moan consists of two figures standing against a grille gate as they are waiting for the train. There is a man on the north bound platform and a woman on the southbound one.  The woman is arriving in town and the man is leaving New York.  Saar spoke of the work:  

The premise for these pieces was to create a simple narrative of two people.  One, the young woman coming to the city in hopes of advancing her career, the other, a successful businees man leaving the city to return to his home town.  I believe these two scenarios to be examples of how many Americans have used the railroad to and from New York throughout history.  Yet I also was addressing the specific and rich tradition of the role of the railroad in general in the lives of African Americans. Ó  

The title, Hear the Lone Whistle Moan, she continues, comes from a spiritual that uses the train as a metaphor for the passage to heaven.  Trains have often been associated by African Americans with escape and the Underground Railroad in particular, which was sometimes referred to as the Phantom Train. 

SaarÕs own ethnic and cultural background is diverse; she traces her ancestry to Europeans and Native Americans as well as African Americans.  A native of California, she attended Scripps College and received an M.F.A. from Otis Art Institute.  She now lives in New York City.

Martha Jackson-Jarvis has experimented with the qualities of fired clay for most of her life, beginning in childhood.  Since then, she has worked with hundreds of clay bodies, kiln types, and glaze forms Ð and she continues to test the various possibilities and to improvise.  While most ceramicists dread the possibility that unexpected contingencies will alter the planned appearance of a work, Jackson-Jarvis welcomes surprise and chance occurrences, noted Curtia James, writing in the January-February 2004 issue of Sculpture.  Speaking of her work for the MTA, the artist says, ÒConceptually, Travelin' Time occupies transitional space. It is a space between points, a place of resting, of waiting, of new beginnings and departures.  Though Mount Vernon station is indeed public space, it still remains an intimate space where human scale and pace are slowed momentarily. It is a space in which we are asked to wait . . . and while waiting contemplate traveling through time and space to distances unknown, yet familiar.Ó

Michele Oka DonerÕs Radiant Site, at the Herald Square subway station Ð one of the busiest transit intersections anywhere Ð is a rectilinear floor-to-ceiling passage bathed in an all-pervasive golden light.  The midsection of the corridor is the brightest, glazed in coppery tiles, but these darken and are less reflective toward the top and bottom of the passage, which are glazed in black.  The resulting glow seems to pulse with gentle energy.

DonerÕs oeuvre includes sculpture, furniture, jewelry, functional objects and public art projects.  She fearlessly, and seemingly effortlessly, crosses disciplines and media to create her varied work.  Her creations are almost never totally abstract; they combine her interest in natural history, anthropology, and archeology with inspirations from nature, mythology and the heavens.  A native of Miami Beach, she is perhaps best known for her miles-long bronze-in-terrazzo concourse floors for Miami International Airport, another work whose aim it is to help humanize the transit environment.

In order to assure control over the effects of her work in Radiant Site, the artist made the 11,000 tiles one-by-one and by hand, on a century-old foot-press at the venerable Pewabic Pottery in Detroit.  Their slightly irregular shapes and uneven surfaces were then hand-glazed, varying the formula in tiny increments so as to achieve the desired luminous effect.  Fingerprints and other irregularities are intentionally left, to stress the organic nature of the process.  

Doner says that in thinking about prospective art projects she considers not only the physical and chemical properties of the materials she will use but also Òtheir psychic and cosmic qualities.Ó  In Radiant Site the composition of the tiles and glazes are manipulated in such a way as to make what would be a gloomy place into one that is reflective and inviting.  ÒI donÕt believe in confrontational art;Ó the artist says, Òthe amount of aggression in the city is already overwhelming.  I think of the project as a spiritual sculpture É   Each of the thousands of people who walk along the wall each day becomes enveloped by this mysterious power.Ó

Michelle GreeneÕs RailridersÕ Throne introduces humor into an otherwise somber subway station.  The artist says, ÒI wanted to create a whimsical environment that allows the commuter to feel special as opposed to alienated.  I believe that art in a public space has the potential to stir people from their daily routine.Ó  And it works.  As reported by Art News in January 1992, a frequent user of the station commented, ÒWhatÕ s weird about that chair is that when you sit in it everyone stares at you.  It feels royal.Ó  Another rider reported, ÒThereÕs a musician who plays his violin.  At first, I thought he brought the chair with him.  I think he makes more money when he sits there.Ó Elements in the design of the chair were influenced by the historic tile pattern in the station, so it nicely reiterates the credo of the original subway designers that ornamental additions to the stations should serve to make the subway a more pleasant place to be.

art_material: Coiled aluminum - chemically etched, Lighting Elements
art_description: In the 34th StreetÐHerald Square subway station riders may be surprised to encounter what seems to be an ethereal vision from the heavens Ð large, luminous orbs appearing to hover in space.  Made of coiled aluminum rods Ð formed in a manner similar to the way in which ceramists sometimes form pots from clay Ð the spheres are suspended on a framework of small beams from the larger steel structural components of the station.  Halo beautifully contrasts the aesthetic with the utilitarian, and the result is  Òan unexpected serenity.Ó  The artist said, ÒIt was my aim to create an enigmatic distribution of objects that would stand in sharp contrast to the rectilinear nature of the site, and in doing so, to establish an oasis of visual language amid an otherwise functional environment.Ó

art_material: Porcelain enamel on ceiling beams in passageway connecting 7th and 8th Ave. lines
art_description: The poem, titled "The Commuter's Lament/A Close Shave," was written by Norman B Colp and was inspired by the famous Burma Shave ad campaign, a men's product that was well known for series of signs across the U.S in the 1920s. The artwork was originally commissioned as a temporary installation, and remains installed in the transfer corridor from 42 St-Port Authority Bus Terminal to Times Sq-42 St. The poem reads: ÒOverslept, so tired, if late, get fired. Why bother? Why the pain? Just go home, do it again.Ó The lines appear mounted on the overhead I-beams, approximately every fifth beam.

Rolando Brise–oÕs At the Table, at North White Plains is a total environment of cast aluminum capitals on the canopy columns along the platforms.  Starting at the stairway and moving down the platform, this piece complements the architecture of the station while presenting a variety of witty, everyday objects etched onto the capitals.  Under six of the station signs, in a black architectonic culmination of the capitals, are pieces that combine these symbols.  Brise–o speaks of the experience of the passenger as similar to moving through a Romanesque cathedral, ÒWhether going to work or coming home, the traveler is drawn into and enlivened by the interactive character of the work.Ó

Sam GilliamÕs Jamaica Center Station Riders, Blue at the Archer Avenue subway station in Queens is composed of two elements: a large ellipse and an armature to which the ellipse is attached, constructed of aluminum plate with deep welds. 

In the artistÕs words, the work is Òcomplex in its simplicityÓ:

 It calls to mind: movement, circuits, speed, technology and passengership. The fact that this is a very modern sculpture places it in contemporary life as well as the future É The colors used in the piece É refer to colors of the respective subway lines. The predominant use of blue provides one with a visual solid in a transitional area that is near subterranean.

Sam Gilliam is referred to as a third-generation ÒWashington Color SchoolÓ artist.  During this period GilliamÕs works became more sculptural or theatrical, where his work was work was interactive with space.  Gilliam literally took the canvas off the frame and onto the wall and used the draped canvas as painting in space.

The color-filled draped canvases led directly to GilliamÕs public work.  Gilliam sculpted Jamaica Center Station Riders, Blue continued to take color and have it interact with wall, but with aluminum as the medium, rather than canvas.

Gilliam is the subject of a full career retrospective at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, DC which is traveling nation-wide from 2005-2007.

In his silhouette figures at the Scarsdale and Hartsdale stations, Tom Nussbaum pays his respects to the types of people most likely to view his artwork there Ð commuters and railroad workers.  At the Hartsdale station, twenty-one life-size figures are placed along the center of the open space between the train tracks.  At the Scarsdale station another group of flattened, iron people appears Ð all in the midst of traveling and carrying along all manner of things. Travelers also includes three-foot figures standing along the roof line of the sta tion canopies.  And giant-sized iron people in the track bed of the Hartsdale station are busy at work guiding trains, maintaining the track and throwing switches.  Nussbaum says, "My approach to this kind of figurative work reflects an on-going interest in American folk sculpture of all kinds, especially whirligigs and weather vanes.Ó

From the artist:  ÒNature's forms have been the inspiration for my work.   I am passionate about our environment.   How a work of public art is integrated into its site and the interplay of ideas with the use of the site are of primary importance.   I like to think about how people will participate with the work, how they will move by, around, through or over it.   With this movement in mind I have made works using several sculptural elements linking areas of a site into a single concept.  I looked at the station Õs existing tile frieze and continued the frieze as a relief tile band.   The relief shows a flight of birds Ð gold when they fly through the gold band and white as they travel over the white tile of the stairwells. I thought of the birds as flying along with the people as both ascend the stairs to the train's elevated platform.Ó
N/A

The disks in Brit BunkleyÕs architectural fantasy Bay Shore Icons illustrate an oblique abstraction of clocks and calendars; the digits found in this artwork are primarily mirror images of numbers.  To highlight the advantages of public transportation, the artist created a cast stone frieze portraying train cars in a traffic jam.  ÒSince I thought the architecture of the waiting areas looked somewhat like a ÔPrairie Style Doric Temple,Õ I designed the extended lintel as a Prairie Style window-like structure (which also mimics the LIRR train windows),Ó said Bunkley in his artistÕs statement for the project.  ÒThe images within it are a sort of Ôsystem of iconsÕ that refer to transportation and aspects of Bay Shore and Fire Island. They include a mirror image pleasure boat, a beach umbrella/arrow with egg (a reference to the egg and dart molding), and a Fire Island lighthouse as a chess piece.Ó

The project consists of a series of fourteen brightly colored paddle-like forms, each twelve feet long, suspended between the east wall of the station and each of the fourteen columns that run the length of the wall.  The artistÕs intent was for the delicately balanced paddles to spin and flutter in the wind generated by approaching and departing trains.  From the artistÕs proposal: ÒAs every veteran subway rider knows Ð whether actively or intuitively Ð the approach of a train is preceded by a gust of wind funneling down the track. It's my interest to build and install a series of subway Ôwind paddlesÕ that will utilize and make visible these subterranean breezes.  The varying amounts of wind will set the brightly colored paddles floating, tilting and spinning in descriptive patterns.Ó

To symbolize the romance and excitement of historic train travel, all under the eye of the railroad conductor, David Saunders immortalized the conductorÕs watch and key chain.  The tubular forms design complement and blend into other, architectural components of the station, particularly its handrails and exposed pipes.  ÒThe chain mimics the movement of the Long Island Rail RoadÕs long silver trains that take commuters to and from their destinations,Ó says Saunders, Òthose speedy back and forth movements are echoed in the long swooping gestures of the sculptureÕs silver lines.Ó

The artwork consists of four large-scale ceramic murals with sculptures of terracotta-colored ceramic tile in architectural formations set into a mosaic background.  The Reliefs Òrelate to the architecture that surrounds them,Ó Olt pointed out in his artistÕs statement for the project, Òto the ebb and flow of humanity that will engulf them and to one another, for a unified design approach to the station.  The Archways represent a symbol of welcome, strength and beauty. Their compelling form and rich color draw influence from Romanesque architecture, augmenting the theme of welcome and adding the theme of continuance in the daily life and work of New Yorkers.  The Gothic Circle component is a symbol of endurance, renewal and perpetuity, and will lend inspiration to daily commuters, spent from their days' toil.  The Greek Temple Quad, a series of four house-shaped pieces, reinforces the theme of welcome and comfort, but itself resembles a cityscape or place of commerce with all the societal vitality that it implies.Ó

In his proposal for El 2 and El 5, Michael Kelly Williams observes that El 2 Òfeatures a snake motif, seen in the track patterns, as well as symbols representing elevated structures and the signal lights in the subway.Ó  And El 5, he says, Òsuggests the movement of elevated trains throughout the city.  Light is a major theme of the piece, especially the burst of light that envelops a subway train when it leaves an underground tunnel and becomes elevated. African and Native American influences are integral to the work, as are arch shapes suggested by tunnels and Ôels.Õ  Charged with energy, color and music, reflecting myth and dance, these fulfill my wish to continue the tradition of mosaics in NYC's subway system."

art_material: Stainless Steel and Aluminum, Lighting Elements, Clock
art_description:
The neo-Deco forms of this giant artwork respond to the architectural integrity of the tunnel ventilation building onto whose side it is visually draped, where it announces the time and provides a glowing welcome.  In the artistÕs words, the clockÕs Òtraditional form and function offer a sense of anticipation, and its sculptural presence instills a sense of wonder by day and at night.Ó  The 86-foot sculpture was commissioned by Arts for Transit and the then Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority (now MTA Bridges and Tunnels) to mark the tunnelÕs fortieth Anniversary.  While it serves to tell travelers the time and to provide necessary illumination, the piece, more importantly, is a work of art.
In the 1970s, R. M. Fischer began working on assemblages of industrial objects, transforming them into sculptures with a futuristic look.  Many of these were made from scavenged, salvaged, and reused metal parts.  In the words of a critic writing in Art in America, ÒAt once nostalgic and futuristic, his wacky inventions transform the mundane and prefabricated into the unique and fantastic.Ó  Clocks were often parts of these earlier works; in Brooklyn-Battery Clock Fischer achieves the same result, if in a more serious manner, but here he designs the object from scratch, from new materials. 
 ÒTunnels are also processional gateways and my work celebrates the passage from one New York City borough to another,Ó the artist has said.  The imagery in the work is a response to the architecture of the tunnelÕs nearby ventilation building and its era, automobile imagery, and engineering design.  The sculptures at the top of the work seen in the foreground as drivers enter the tunnel on their way to Brooklyn evoke Coney Island and its famous amusement parks.  The intent of the materials, scale and design aspects of the installation is that the sculpture, along with the lighting treatment, is integrated with the existing architecture to present a single unified composition.

From the artistÕs proposal:  ÒI will create a series of tiles tracing the history of Long Island, beginning in the Ice Age, through paintings of rocks and plant life. The next stage would show how the Native Americans interacted with plants and sea life, followed by the first Europeans, who settled in Long Island and established farms and a seafaring industry. Later, a tourist industry developed, as well as several advanced industries. The early history of Merrick describes developed grain farms with cows and sheep. At the same time, Bellmore was developing a fishing industry.  The railroad eventually became a bridging device to bring together the surrounding communities and contributed greatly to the development of contemporary Long Island.Ó

At the same time, Bellmore was developing a fishing industry.  The railroad eventually became a bridging device to bring together the surrounding communities and contributed greatly to the development of contemporary Long Island.Ó

The hundreds of brilliant facets of Romare BeardenÕs glass triptych throb with life, woven together by the heavy black thread of a subway train wending its way from tenements to skyscrapers.  The work began as a collage maquette; this was then faithfully and skillfully enlarged and transformed into a glowing artwork in jewel-like colored glass. 

Bearden graduated from New York University with a degree in mathematics, and also studied art history and philosophy at the Sorbonne in Paris, where he met Braque, Matisse, and Mir—.  He also knew the American artist Stuart Davis, who had a marked effect on his work.  Interestingly, early in his career he was employed for a time as a songwriter and also worked as a social worker.  Both experiences would later be reflected in his art.  

Bearden consistently maintained that his concern was with universal human themes, not just those pertaining only to African Americans:  ÒI work out of a response and need to redefine the image of man in the terms of the Negro experience I know best.Ó  Or, as renowned writer Ralph Ellison said in a 1980 Mint Museum catalogue essay, ÒBearden's art is not only an evaluation of his own freedom and responsibility as an individual and artist, it is an affirmation of the irrelevance of the notion of race as a limiting force in the arts.  These are works of a man possessing a rare lucidity of vision.Ó  

City of Light, is classic Bearden as it skillfully weaves together the spirit found in his beloved music, social concerns and his interest in trains.  Rendered in his characteristically bright colors, the work was the result of a long collaboration between Romare Bearden and the fabricators, Benoit Gilsoul and Helmut Schardt.   Following the artistÕs death in 1988, they were able to complete the work from the preparatory studies and instructions he had left behind.

art_title: Ghost Series: Corinthian Capital, Plinth, Day and Night, Mercury Man, Broken Column, Drawing of Old Pennsylvania Station
art_description:
Walking from Eighth Avenue down the long, long concourse in the Long Island Rail Road section of Pennsylvania Station, commuters may find themselves transfixed on an enormous black circular form at the far end, surrounded by what appears to be gloomy giant statuary.  Or having descended one of the escalators from 34th  Street they may find it a bit unsettling to be confronted with enormous columns hurtling downward and in the process being shattered.  There is nothing cheerful here Ð and intentionally so.

These are parts of Andrew LeicesterÕs Ghost Series, five towering bas-relief terra cotta murals scattered throughout the station corridors.  These invoke the lost world of the buildingÕs illustrious precursor, the majestic 1910 Beaux-Arts structure by McKim, Mead and White that was demolished in 1963 Ð which the artist calls Òthe sacrificial lamb that initiated the historic preservation movement in the United States.Ó   But Leicester points out that fragments of the old Penn Station are hidden in the lower depths of the building that replaced it; these murals symbolically reveal the old building now ignominiously concealed behind new walls Ð and buried in the landfills of New JerseyÕs Meadowlands.  

In Ghost: Day and Night, a 500 square-foot-mural at the Seventh Avenue end of the main concourse, Leicester has reinterpreted Adolph WinemanÕs sculpture of the same name that presided over the old stationÕs entrances, depicting two voluptuous women flanking a gigantic clock.  The artist has embedded the date on which the original building was destroyed Ð 10/28/63 Ð into the clockÕs otherwise blank face.  Other murals include Mercury Man, a reproduction of another sculptural figure with anonymous fragments from the original building, as well as a large-scale porcelain-on-steel rendering of one of the blueprints for the demolished building.  Taken together, Ghost Series is a thoroughly compelling and fitting memento mori.

Deborah BrownÕs Platform Diving shows realistically rendered marine animals doing oddly human things.  A manatee is patiently anticipating the arrival of the next train.  A whale reads a commuterÕs newspaper over his shoulder.  Turtles dive off a platform of the station.  ÒI wanted to explore the analogy between subway travel and the movement of our fellow creatures through their natural environment,Ó Brown says.  ÒUnderwater creatures navigate a complex spatial array of undersea passageways, much as we maneuver through our own manmade systems.  I thought it would be provocative to portray them in a part of our world most closely resembling their own, but involved in activities familiar to us.Ó

In this series of 22 panels, in a recessed area above the subway station sign, symbolic figures move about and interact with one another. Although separated by spacing between panels, each is linked by color to form a relationship with those nearby.  The artist explained his concept in his proposal:  ÒAs a unit they form a composite to symbolically show as in a ÔUnionÕ  the best of each part of racial, religious and cultural life make the most positive picture.  The community above the Union Street station is mirrored in these panels because they are successfully working at making their community into this reality.Ó  Additionally, the station has a series of wall panels designed by the artist, which feature primary and secondary colors; red, yellow, blue, green, and orange.  Wigglesworth, a native of Philadelphia, is a muralist, painter, sculptor, poet, printmaker, fabric designer and poet.

art_material: Porcelain enamel, Ceramic tile with text
art_description: Josh ScharfÕs Carnegie Hall Montage takes as its theme the staggering number of illustrious people who have appeared on the famous buildingÕ s stage.  The work consists of two parts, a mural with large, vivid images of some of the greats who have appeared there Ð Tchaikovsky, Eleanor Roosevelt, Leonard Bernstein, Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Beatles Ð and dozens of small white tiles in station entryways inscribed with the dates of appearances of still others, ranging from Alexander Graham Bell to Helen Keller.  Carnegie Hall, which was paid for by the philanthropist Andrew Carnegie opened in 1891 with no less than Tchaikovsky cond ucting, still bills itself as Òthe premier classical music performance space in the United States.Ó  In the twentieth century, it expanded its repertoire from classical instrumental and vocal performances to include jazz and popular music performances, lectures, and other educational programs.

The ornamental barriers at 23rd Street were so successful that the MTA determined that new, artist-designed railings similar to these should be incorporated system-wide.  Laura Bradley was at that time creating City Suite, a mosaic artwork for the 96th Street and Lexington Avenue station.  The first ÒmovementÓ of the tile work is a terrazzo square that elegantly surrounds a column on the stationÕs mezzanine.  Two large mosaic medallions form the visual centerpiece of the work. Bradley created new name tablets that appear to be original and yet they incorporate her medallion design. The City Suite mosaics were her inspiration in creating the designs that would be translated into metalwork forms at 96th Street; subsequently, her stylized forms were adopted for use throughout the subway system, where they lift the institutional-like feeling the standard railings throughout the subway produced. ÒThey are functional, but they also seek to create an intuitive harmony that people respond to.Ó

The subject of The Greenwich Village Murals is the neighborhoodÕs long and intriguing history.  They are amalgamations of childrenÕs drawings assembled and arranged by artist Lee Brozgold, who first set out to commemorate only a few famous people. ÒBut the Village is so rich in amazing characters who shaped America that picking only twelve was impossible,Ó he says.  The cut-off point was then decided to be forty.  A chronological arrangement was considered, but this too proved problematic.  BrozgoldÕs final decision was to group them into four ÒmovementsÓ: Founders, Providers, Bohemians, and Rebels.  Brozgold was assisted by student artists from P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village, whose images were selected by Deborah Lewis, a teacher at the school.

In her surrealistic The Way Out, Liliana PorterÕs silhouette figures capture characters from Lewis CarrollÕs Alice in Wonderland and imbue them with life.  These were intended by the artist to refer to the many Broadway theaters nearby aboveground.  The link is a general, conceptual one.  The artist evokes the idea of the theatrical and subtly and playfully connects it with the idea of being underground.    To make the theater reference more specific, Porter shows Alice pulling back a curtain to reveal the drama.  Porter, an Argentinian artist living in the United States, prefers to let the viewerÕs imagination fill in the details of her shadowy figures, playing on our varying views of reality, observed the New York Times in an September 21, 2003, article.

art_material: Sandblasted and Laminated Glass Windows, Steel Railings (stair railing & exterior fence)
art_description: Approaching these historic stations, ridersÕ attention is first drawn to the railings of the station entrances and of the downward-leading stairwells; these suggest trellises from neighborhood gardens.  The floral motif continues as one goes farther; next are columns adorned with abstractions of flower forms.  Decorative inserts in the railings hark back to the original fences of the facilities.  And finally, the station opens up visually to the outside; large window openings with floral motifs repeated from the fencing outline the tracks below. Patsy Norvell, the artist, says of Garden Stops:  ÒIt is an environment that surrounds you rather than something you stop to look at.  As viewers pass through, the workÕs elements evoke the history of the stations, trigger peopleÕs own memories, and a spark a kind of inner dialogue about space, nature, and change.Ó

As viewers pass through, the workÕs elements evoke the history of the stations, trigger peopleÕs own memories, and a spark a kind of inner dialogue about space, nature, and change.Ó

Dating from 1919, the Prospect Park and Parkside Avenue stations on the Brighton Beach line feature distinctive Òhead houses,Ó covered entrance structures located above the stations.  Their wall tiles and ceramic borders are also historic, characteristic of the Arts and Crafts movement influential at that time.   In newly reconfigured areas of the stations Susan Tunick designed new ceramic murals and borders different from but reminiscent of the old.  The leaf motifs of these works derive, she says, from childhood memories of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and Prospect Park, both nearby, as well as her longstanding interest in ceramic history and modern artistic expressions in fired clay.  Tunick has long been involved as a leader of Friends of Terra Cotta where she has successfully crusaded in New York and nationally to save and restore ceramic architectural forms on significant buildings and monuments.
